healthy.name: Healthy
healthy.description: Plant shows no signs of disease or nutrient deficiency; foliage is uniformly colored and turgid, growth is consistent with species expectations.
cure_tips: No treatment required; maintain regular good cultural practices such as proper watering and light.

anthracnose.name: Anthracnose
anthracnose.description: A fungal disease causing dark, sunken lesions on leaves, stems, or fruit; favours warm, wet conditions and can cause premature defoliation and disfigurement.
symptoms: Dark, water-soaked spots that enlarge into sunken lesions on leaves or stems.
Leaf yellowing and premature leaf drop in severe infections.
Lesions may coalesce, producing irregular dead areas on foliage.
cure_tips: Remove and destroy infected plant debris and heavily affected tissues to reduce inoculum.
Improve air circulation and avoid overhead watering to reduce leaf wetness.
Apply appropriate fungicides (e.g., copper-based or chlorothalonil) following label instructions during active infection.

leaf_withering.name: Leaf Withering
leaf_withering.description: A symptom complex where leaves wilt and brown due to water stress, root problems, vascular disease, or environmental extremes; underlying causes must be diagnosed for correct treatment.
symptoms: Progressive wilting of older or new leaves despite watering.
Leaf margins browning and curling under stress.
Plants may appear stunted or show reduced vigor.
cure_tips: Check soil moisture and root health; correct under- or over-watering.
Inspect roots for rot or pests and repot into fresh, well-draining medium if needed.
Improve drainage and avoid waterlogged conditions; consider targeted fungicide if vascular fungi are suspected.

fungal_leaf_spot.name: Fungal Leaf Spot
fungal_leaf_spot.description: Caused by various fungal pathogens producing small to large necrotic spots on leaves; spread is promoted by moisture and crowded plants, reducing photosynthetic area and vigor.
symptoms: Small circular to irregular brown or black spots on leaf surfaces.
Spots may have concentric rings or a pale halo.
Severe infections cause coalescing lesions and leaf yellowing.
cure_tips: Remove affected leaves and dispose of them; do not compost infected material.
Space plants to increase airflow and avoid overhead watering.
Use registered fungicides when outbreaks are severe and follow label directions.

foliar_necrosis.name: Foliar Necrosis
foliar_necrosis.description: Localised death of leaf tissue resulting from severe disease, chemical injury, or abiotic stress; appears as brown or black dead patches and can indicate systemic problems.
symptoms: Distinct patches of dead, brown or black tissue on leaves.
Necrotic areas may be dry, sunken, or surrounded by a chlorotic halo.
Progressive spread can lead to major leaf loss.
cure_tips: Identify and eliminate the cause (chemical burn, nutrient imbalance, or pathogen).
Trim necrotic tissue and improve plant care (water, light, and fertilization balance).
Treat confirmed infections with targeted fungicides or bactericides as appropriate.

healthy.name: Healthy
healthy.description: No visible disease signs; leaves are firm and evenly colored, and growth is consistent with normal species characteristics under current care.
cure_tips: Maintain stable moisture, moderate light, and inspect regularly for pests to keep plants healthy.

bacterial_wilt.name: Bacterial Wilt
bacterial_wilt.description: A bacterial disease (e.g., Ralstonia spp.) that blocks vascular tissue causing rapid wilting and plant collapse; often fatal and spread by contaminated soil, tools or water.
symptoms: Sudden wilting of leaves while foliage may remain green initially.
Sticky or foul-smelling ooze from cut stems in advanced stages.
Progressive collapse of the plant over days to weeks.
cure_tips: Remove and destroy severely infected plants to prevent spread.
Avoid moving soil between plants and sterilize tools after use.
Practice crop rotation and use disease-free planting material where possible.

chlorosis.name: Chlorosis
chlorosis.description: Yellowing of leaf tissue due to insufficient chlorophyll from nutrient deficiencies (commonly iron or magnesium), poor root health, or alkaline soils reducing nutrient availability.
symptoms: Interveinal yellowing on young or new leaves if iron deficiency; older leaves if magnesium.
Overall pale appearance despite normal watering.
Growth may be slowed and leaves smaller than typical.
cure_tips: Test soil or substrate and correct pH if alkaline to improve nutrient uptake.
Apply appropriate foliar or soil-applied micronutrient chelates (e.g., iron chelate) as needed.
Improve root health by avoiding waterlogging and ensuring adequate drainage.

manganese_toxicity.name: Manganese Toxicity
manganese_toxicity.description: Excess manganese accumulation in acidic or waterlogged soils causing leaf spotting, interveinal chlorosis, and reduced growth; often associated with imbalance of other micronutrients.
symptoms: Small brown or black spots and interveinal chlorosis on leaves.
Stunted growth and bronzing of older foliage in advanced cases.
Symptoms more pronounced in acidic, poorly drained soils.
cure_tips: Adjust soil pH toward neutral and improve drainage to reduce Mn availability.
Avoid manganese-containing fertilizers until levels normalize.
Apply balanced fertilization to correct competing nutrient imbalances (e.g., calcium or magnesium).

healthy.name: Healthy
healthy.description: Plant appears vigorous with normal leaf color and flower production, showing no signs of disease or nutrient stress under current cultural conditions.
cure_tips: Continue good cultural practices: adequate watering, balanced fertilization, and monitoring for pests and diseases.

bacterial_leaf_spot.name: Bacterial Leaf Spot
bacterial_leaf_spot.description: Bacterial pathogens create water-soaked lesions that later dry into tan or brown spots; spread by splashing water, contaminated tools, and infected transplants.
symptoms: Water-soaked, dark spots that may become tan or brown and angular.
Yellowing around lesions and possible defoliation in severe cases.
Lesions often follow leaf veins and enlarge under wet conditions.
cure_tips: Remove infected foliage and avoid overhead irrigation to reduce splashing spread.
Sterilize tools and use disease-free transplants to limit introduction.
Use copper-based bactericides as a protective measure during active outbreaks.

septoria_leaf_spot.name: Septoria Leaf Spot
septoria_leaf_spot.description: A fungal disease (Septoria spp.) causing numerous small, round, tan to brown leaf spots often with a darker border; thrives in wet, crowded conditions and reduces foliage density.
symptoms: Many small circular tan to brown spots with possible dark borders on lower leaves.
Premature yellowing and defoliation when infections are heavy.
Spore production leads to rapid spread under prolonged leaf wetness.
cure_tips: Remove and dispose of infected leaves; improve spacing and airflow.
Avoid overhead watering and water early in the day to hasten drying.
Apply appropriate fungicides when cultural controls are insufficient and follow label directions.

healthy.name: Healthy
healthy.description: No disease signs present; leaves, stems, and blooms show normal color and turgor, indicating adequate cultural conditions.
cure_tips: Maintain balanced watering and fertilization; monitor regularly for pests and early disease signs.

blight.name: Blight
blight.description: A rapid, severe disease (bacterial or fungal) causing extensive browning and dieback of foliage and stems; commonly favoured by humid, wet conditions and poor airflow.
symptoms: Rapid browning and wilting of large leaf areas and young shoots.
Stem lesions and dieback can follow leaf symptoms.
Infected tissue often becomes water-soaked before turning brown and necrotic.
cure_tips: Prune and destroy affected tissues and improve plant spacing for airflow.
Reduce overhead irrigation and remove sources of splash (mulch, ground water).
Apply labeled bactericides or fungicides if the causal agent is identified and conditions warrant.

foliar_necrosis.name: Foliar Necrosis
foliar_necrosis.description: Localized death of leaf tissue often caused by severe disease, chemical injury, or environmental stress; results in brown, dry patches that reduce photosynthetic area.
symptoms: Brown to black dead patches on leaf surfaces, often irregular in shape.
Necrotic areas may be dry and brittle, sometimes with surrounding chlorosis.
Severe necrosis reduces plant vigor and flowering.
cure_tips: Identify and remove the triggerâ€”adjust cultural practices or eliminate chemical exposure.
Trim necrotic tissue and maintain optimal watering and nutrient balance.
Treat identifiable pathogens with appropriate fungicides or bactericides as required.

sun_scorch.name: Sun Scorch
sun_scorch.description: Tissue damage from excessive direct sunlight or sudden exposure leading to pale, bleached, or brown burnt leaf areas; often occurs after moving plants to higher light too quickly.
symptoms: Bleached, pale or brown patches on the sun-exposed side of leaves.
Leaf edges may curl and become dry and papery.
New growth may be more sensitive and show signs first.
cure_tips: Move sensitive plants to gradual higher light or provide partial shade during peak sun.
Avoid sudden changes in light exposure when relocating plants.
Keep plants well watered during heat spells to reduce stress.

healthy.name: Healthy
healthy.description: Plant displays expected vigor with healthy foliage and flower development; no visible pest or disease symptoms under current care.
cure_tips: Continue good cultural care and monitor for common Rosaceae pests and diseases like fungal infections and aphids.

black_spot.name: Black Spot
black_spot.description: A common fungal disease (Diplocarpon rosae) of roses causing round black spots with fringed edges on leaves, leading to yellowing and defoliation under wet conditions.
symptoms: Distinct black circular spots on upper leaf surfaces often with yellow halos.
Leaves yellow and drop prematurely in moderate to severe infections.
Disease progresses rapidly in cool, wet seasons.
cure_tips: Remove and dispose of infected leaves; thin canopy to improve air movement.
Water at the base of plants and avoid wetting foliage.
Use fungicidal sprays (e.g., chlorothalonil or systemic fungicides) according to label recommendations.

downy_mildew.name: Downy Mildew
downy_mildew.description: Caused by oomycetes producing fuzzy or downy growth on undersides of leaves, leading to chlorosis, necrosis, and defoliation in cool, moist conditions.
symptoms: Pale, yellow or brown patches on upper leaf surfaces with fuzzy, downy growth beneath.
Leaf curling and premature leaf drop in affected plants.
Infections are patchy and favored by cool, humid weather.
cure_tips: Improve drainage and airflow; avoid overhead watering and wet foliage.
Remove severely affected leaves and sanitize tools.
Apply appropriate fungicides or oomycete-specific treatments when necessary and follow label instructions.

generic_insect_damage.name: Generic Insect Damage
generic_insect_damage.description: Damage caused by various chewing or sucking insects (e.g., caterpillars, beetles, aphids) producing holes, skeletonized leaves, or distorted growth and potentially transmitting diseases.
symptoms: Chewed leaf edges, holes, or skeletonized foliage from chewing insects.
Distorted, curled, or sticky leaves where sap-sucking insects feed.
Presence of insects, frass, or honeydew on plant surfaces.
cure_tips: Inspect plants frequently and hand-remove larger pests when feasible.
Use insecticidal soaps or horticultural oils for soft-bodied pests like aphids.
Introduce or encourage beneficial predators and consider targeted insecticides for severe infestations.

mosaic_virus.name: Mosaic Virus
mosaic_virus.description: Viral infections that produce mottled light and dark green patterns on leaves, often stunting growth and reducing yield; viruses spread by grafting, sap contact, or insect vectors.
symptoms: Mottled, mosaic-like patterns of light and dark green on leaves.
Stunted growth and reduced flowering or fruiting in affected plants.
Symptoms are persistent and do not respond to fungicides or bactericides.
cure_tips: Remove and destroy infected plants to prevent spread via vectors or tools.
Control insect vectors (e.g., aphids) with cultural or chemical measures.
Use certified virus-free planting material and practice strict sanitation.

mildew.name: Mildew
mildew.description: Powdery or downy fungal infections that form white to gray powdery growth or fuzzy patches on leaves, reducing photosynthesis and vigor when severe.
symptoms: White to gray powdery coating on upper leaf surfaces (powdery mildew).
Leaf curling, distortion, and reduced vigor in infected areas.
In severe cases, flowers and buds may be affected or deformed.
cure_tips: Promote good airflow and avoid excess nitrogen fertilization that encourages lush, susceptible growth.
Remove heavily infected tissue and dispose of it away from plants.
Apply appropriate fungicides labeled for powdery or downy mildew when cultural controls fail.

rust.name: Rust
rust.description: Fungal disease producing orange, rust-colored pustules on leaf undersides and sometimes upper surfaces; can weaken plants and spread rapidly in moist conditions.
symptoms: Orange, yellow or reddish pustules on underside of leaves and spots on upper surfaces.
Premature leaf yellowing and drop with heavy infections.
Often has alternate host cycles and appears seasonally in moist weather.
cure_tips: Remove and destroy infected leaves and nearby alternate hosts if identified.
Space plants for improved airflow and avoid overhead irrigation.
Use fungicides effective against rust when infections are persistent and severe.

yellow_mosaic_virus.name: Yellow Mosaic Virus
yellow_mosaic_virus.description: A viral disease causing yellow mosaic patterns or mottling on leaves, often reducing plant vigor and yield; transmitted by insect vectors such as aphids or whiteflies.
symptoms: Yellow mosaic or mottled patterns across leaf blades causing uneven coloration.
Stunted growth and reduced flowering or fruit set.
Symptoms persist and cannot be cured with chemical treatments.
cure_tips: Remove and destroy infected plants and control vector insects promptly.
Use virus-free certified stock and practice strict sanitation when grafting or propagating.
Implement reflective mulches or insect barriers to reduce vector transmission where practical.

healthy.name: Healthy
healthy.description: No visible signs of disease; foliage and rhizomes appear healthy and growth is consistent for the species under correct cultural conditions.
cure_tips: Maintain balanced moisture, good drainage, and inspect rhizomes at planting to ensure healthy stock.

aphids.name: Aphids
aphids.description: Small sap-sucking insects that cluster on new growth, producing honeydew and potentially transmitting viral diseases; heavy infestations weaken plants and distort leaves.
symptoms: Clusters of small soft-bodied insects on undersides of leaves and new shoots.
Sticky honeydew and sooty mold growth on surfaces below infestations.
Distorted, curled or yellowing new leaves from feeding damage.
cure_tips: Wash off small infestations with a strong water spray or hand-remove colonies.
Use insecticidal soaps or horticultural oils against persistent aphid populations.
Encourage natural enemies like ladybirds and lacewings to suppress populations biologically.

necrotic_fungal_lesion.name: Necrotic Fungal Lesion
necrotic_fungal_lesion.description: Localized dead spots on leaves or stems caused by fungal pathogens leading to brown or black lesions that can enlarge and coalesce under warm, humid conditions.
symptoms: Brown to black necrotic spots on leaves that may have a water-soaked margin.
Lesions can enlarge and merge, causing large dead areas on foliage.
Severe infection reduces photosynthetic area and overall vigor.
cure_tips: Remove and destroy affected leaves and maintain good field hygiene.
Improve spacing and airflow to reduce humidity around foliage.
Apply suitable fungicides according to product labels when cultural measures are insufficient.

foliar_necrosis.name: Foliar Necrosis
foliar_necrosis.description: Death of leaf tissue often resulting from pathogens, nutrient imbalances, or environmental stress; appears as brown, dry patches reducing plant health and yield.
symptoms: Brown, dry dead patches on leaf tissues often starting at tips or margins.
Affected areas may be brittle and flake off, leaving holes.
Progressive spread can lead to reduced rhizome development and vigor.
cure_tips: Correct cultural stresses (water, nutrients) and remove severely affected tissue.
Improve drainage and avoid prolonged leaf wetness to limit fungal growth.
Treat confirmed fungal causes with appropriate fungicides following label directions.

fungal_leaf_spot.name: Fungal Leaf Spot
fungal_leaf_spot.description: Various foliar fungi cause discrete spots on leaves that can reduce photosynthesis and spread rapidly in moist conditions; management focuses on sanitation and moisture control.
symptoms: Distinct circular or irregular brown spots on leaves, sometimes with a pale center.
Lower leaves often affected first and may yellow and drop.
Rapid spread under prolonged wet or humid weather.
cure_tips: Remove infected leaves and sanitize tools to reduce spread.
Improve plant spacing and water early in the day to allow drying.
Use registered fungicides when cultural controls are insufficient and according to label guidance.

healthy.name: Healthy
healthy.description: No disease symptoms observed; foliage shows normal color and form, and plant growth is steady under proper care.
cure_tips: Maintain consistent care, avoid overwatering, and monitor for common fungal and pest issues.

anthracnose.name: Anthracnose
anthracnose.description: Fungal disease producing dark, sunken lesions on leaves, stems or flowers; favored by wet conditions and causing defoliation and poor plant appearance if unchecked.
symptoms: Sunken, dark lesions on leaves or stems that may enlarge and merge.
Leaf yellowing and premature drop in infected plants.
Lesions may be more numerous in shaded, humid areas.
cure_tips: Remove infected material and provide better air circulation and light.
Avoid overhead watering and water earlier in the day to reduce leaf wetness.
Apply appropriate fungicides when necessary and follow label instructions.

generic_fungal_leaf_spot.name: Generic Fungal Leaf Spot
generic_fungal_leaf_spot.description: A general category for numerous fungal pathogens that cause discrete leaf spots; management centers on sanitation, cultural controls, and fungicide use when needed.
symptoms: Small circular to irregular dark spots on leaves, sometimes with halos.
Lower leaves often infected first, becoming yellow and dropping.
Spots may coalesce leading to larger necrotic areas.
cure_tips: Remove and discard infected leaves and avoid working when plants are wet.
Improve spacing and airflow, and water at the base of plants.
Apply fungicides when outbreaks persist despite cultural measures.

rust.name: Rust
rust.description: Fungal infection producing rust-colored pustules on leaf undersides; repeated infections weaken plants and are promoted by humid conditions and wet foliage.
symptoms: Orange to brown pustules or powdery spores on leaf undersides.
Yellowing and premature defoliation with severe infections.
Pustules may rub off leaving colored dust on hands or clothing.
cure_tips: Remove infected leaves and avoid allowing foliage to stay wet for long periods.
Space plants to improve airflow and reduce humidity around leaves.
Treat with fungicides effective against rust when necessary and follow label directions.

sun_scorch.name: Sun Scorch
sun_scorch.description: Leaf tissue damage due to excessive sunlight or sudden exposure changes causing bleached or brown burnt areas; often linked to heat or water stress.
symptoms: Pale, bleached areas or brown burned patches on sun-exposed leaf surfaces.
Leaf edges may become dry, curled, and brittle.
Damage is often most apparent after sudden increases in light intensity.
cure_tips: Provide gradual acclimation to higher light and use shade during peak sun periods.
Ensure adequate soil moisture during hot weather to reduce stress.
Avoid moving shade-adapted plants suddenly into full sun exposure.
